metadata.title: Wartenberg's Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: As the radial nerve enters the forearm, it bifurcates, with the superficial radial nerve (SRN) being one of the two diverting branches. The SRN then continues distally down the radial side of the forearm between the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus, where it eventually terminates into the dorsal digital nerves. As the SRN traverses the forearm, it becomes most superficial at about 9 cm proximal to the radial styloid process(1)
The SRN provides sensation to the dorsal thumb, index, middle finger, and areas proximal to the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints(1)
description: Wartenberg’s syndrome is an injury to or compression/entrapment of the SRN along any portion of the nerve tract. The offending stimulus is usually direct trauma, external compression, or a mass(2)

ICD-10 codes.G56.30: lesion of radial nerve, unspecified upper limb (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8984: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8985: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8986: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Self Care G-code set.G8987: Self care functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Self Care G-code set.G8988: Self care functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Self Care G-code set.G8989: Self care functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8990: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8991: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8992: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8993: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8994: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8995: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Sensory symptoms limited to lateral one third of forearm, lateral wrist and hand, and dorsum of hand to web space between middle and ring fingers (to PIP joint)
Paresthesia and hypesthesia in the distribution of the SRN
Pain (in the form of electric shock) may radiate from the radial forearm to the dorsal thumb and index finger(3)
Repetitive wrist movements, especially twisting when pouring drinks, can aggravate the pain(3)
Pain rather than dysfunction is the major complaint
Motor weakness is not seen with this condition Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Extreme pain and edema may limit examination in the acute stage. Physician may perform digital block to decrease pain during assessment

causes: Wearing tight bracelets or an overly tightened wristwatch(1)
Compression by space-occupying  mass (tumor, ganglion cyst)(2)
Repeated exposure to extremely cold temperature(6)
Repetitive wrist dorsiflexion with the wrist joint loaded(7)
Tenosynovitis in de Quervain’s disease may lead to irritation of the nearby SRN; 48% of those with Wartenberg’s syndromehave also been found to have de Quervain’s disease(5)
pathogenesis: Although entrapment or compression can occur anywhere along the pathway of the SRN, the most common site ofentrapment is usually between the brachioradialis tendon and extensor carpi radialis longus tendon(5)

As the forearm undergoes pronation and supination, the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus tendons convergeonto and diverge away from the SRN, respectively. The “scissor-like” action of these two tendons during forearm motioncan subsequently compress the nerve(5)
The SRN is believed to be most susceptible to compression at the posterior border of the brachioradialis as the nervebecomes more superficial(1)
risk factors: No age-specific  or occupational risk factors have been identified in epidemiological studies
The SRN is the most commonly affected nerve (89%) in peripheral nerve injuries induced from overtightened handcuffs(4)
There have been individual reports of alcohol use being associated with Wartenberg’s syndrome(4)
Use of a constrictive wrist bands or racquetball straps have been reported to cause Wartenberg’s syndrome(8)

overall contraindications precautions: Because a high percentage of cases of Wartenberg’s syndrome involve de Quervain’s disease, detection of the two conditions concomitantly present in a patient must be uncovered or an iatrogenic injury may result, especially during postsurgical management(5)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Extreme pain and edema may limit examination in the acute stage. Physician may perform digital block to decrease pain during assessment

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did symptoms first appear? -What were the symptoms at onset and how have they progressed? -Was a traumatic event involved, or did symptoms slowly surface? -What was the patient doing just prior to the emergence of symptoms? -Does the patient wear jewelry or equipment around the wrists?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Ask about patient’s past and current medical management How has the pain responded to treatment? Did the patient have surgery for this problem? Does the patient wear a splint?
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs are commonly prescribed
diagnostic tests completed: Radiographs to assess the wrist and rule out fracture
MRI to rule out tumors and cysts(2)
Electromyographic and nerve conduction studies to assess degree and location of nerve damage, as well as course of recovery, but are of limited value in this condition
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Note length of time each activity is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased -Carrying, lifting, and pouring drinks may elicit immediate symptoms, requiring several minutes to rest and allow for symptoms to subside(3)
history of present illness.body chart: Body chart -Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Symptoms limited to lateral one third of forearm, lateral (radial) wrist and hand, and dorsum of hand to web space between middle and ring fingers (to proximal interphalangeal joint) -Pain may radiate into the hand from the dorsal wrist near the radial styloid process
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Ask about onset of symptoms (sudden or gradual) and how they have changed over time -Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Symptoms are commonly described as a constant, burning pain, with occasional electric-like shocks(3)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior wrist/hand problems, fractures, or surgery?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Comorbid diagnoses Ask the patient about other diagnoses, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Recent pregnancy? Inquire about alcohol use(4)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs and supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient wear bracelets or tie objects around the involved wrist? -Ask about adverse effects of condition on occupational and recreational activities -Inquire about repetitive wrist movements at work -In a case series of 15 patients with Wartenberg’s syndrome, 33.3% had work-related symptoms(9)
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Stairs and number of floors in home? -With whom does patient live? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: In patients wearing a splint/orthosis, assess hand function with splint/orthosis on and off to assure that splint/orthosis allows mobility of thumb and fingers
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Radial pulses and capillary filling of the hand should be assessed. Although typically normal, in the case of overtightened handcuffs or bracelets, circulation may concomitantly be compromised(4) Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Evaluate upper limb neurodynamic mobility, especially in a modified SRN biased position(3) -Position patient in a Finkelstein test position (clenched fist around a flexed thumb with the wrist in ulnar deviation) -Compare bilaterally Joint integrity and mobility –Assess accessory motion of radiocarpal and intercarpal joints, which should not be impaired by this condition –If indicated, screen cervical spine, shoulder, and elbow joints to uncover any proximal involvement(3)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess handgrip and pinch-grip  strength. Intrinsic muscle strength of involved hand should be normal(10) –Also assess the strength of dorsal and radial forearm muscles. These muscles are innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve and should be normal(10) –Any weakness found (handgrip, pinch-grip,  or wrist drop) is a sign of a proximal radial nerve injury or more severe condition not associated with Wartenberg’s syndrome(1)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess integrity of skin in distribution area for dryness and irritation (flaking, scaling, and redness)
Assess involved area for deformities, possible neuroma/cyst, and adhesions/trophic changes
Look for signs of compression, such as ecchymosis, hand edema, or lacerations(4)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess upper extremity alignment at elbow and wrist –Also assess head, shoulder, and spine posture as misalignments in these areas may affect peripheral nerve mobility(3)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Measure active and passive range of motion (ROM) at wrist (flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation) and forearm using a goniometer; pronation may elicit symptoms. Compare to uninvolved side –Screen cervical spine, shoulder, and elbow ROM to uncover any proximal involvement(3)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Determine whether there are deficits in hand function/dexterity that may limit independence in self-care  or other activities of daily living. The manual ability measure (MAM) may be useful for assessing UE use for functional tasks(16,17)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Upper-extremity  deep tendon reflexes should be normal
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation in distribution of SRN. A patient with Wartenberg’s syndrome may have diminished sensation to touch and pinprick over the dorsoradial hand, thumb, and index finger(10)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisThis is a test for assessing the presence of an irritated SRN. A light percussion is performed by the examiner(5)Under the brachioradialis tendonWristwatch levelFirst compartment level (at the radial styloid process)Distal to Zone III –A positive Tinel’s sign will reproduce symptoms a patient with Wartenberg’s syndrome complains of (i.e., numbness, tingling, burning into the dorsal thumb, index, and middle finger)May elicit symptoms due to the traction placed on the SRN

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions(12) -Do not place electrodes near: -Carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs), phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads, areas with known peripheral vascular disease, areas with hemorrhage, areas with active osteomyelitis -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease (e.g., uncontrolled hyper-  or hypo-tension,  irregular heart rate) -Malignancy/neoplasms -Electrodes near compromised skin or neck/craniofacial regions in patients with a history of seizures or cerebrovascular accident (CV A) -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen or with a history of spontaneous abortion
other: Avoid repetitive wrist extension with ulnar deviation
Tenosynovitis in de Quervain’s disease may lead to inflammation of the nearby superficial radial nerve(11) (see Clinical Review … de Quervain’ s Syndrome ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708422)

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Painful symptoms in the distribution of the SRN that interfere with daily activities. Therapy referral after surgical decompression
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out De Quervain’s disease(1) Degenerative joint disease of wrist joint Radial tunnel syndrome(3) Posterior interosseous neuropathy Wartenberg’s migrant sensory neuritis Radial nerve palsy Ganglion cyst, neuroma(13) Carpal tunnel syndrome Lateral antebrachial cutaneous neuritis(1) Cervical radiculopathy(3)
prognosis: Spontaneous recovery from Wartenberg’s syndrome is common(1)
Rehabilitation may take as long as 3 months(10)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Hand surgeon Occupational/physical therapist with hand therapy experience
other considerations: A single cortisone injection may be considered by the physician,(10) but efficacy has not been established(1)
Wartenberg’s syndrome may present with symptoms over the 1st dorsal compartment of the hand, which can be misdiagnosed as de Quervain’s disease(1)

A patient with sensory symptoms consistent with Wartenberg’s syndrome along with weakness in muscles innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve will most likely have a lesion that is more proximal, such as a cervical radiculopathy(1)

Wartenberg’s sign is the abduction or clawing of the little finger with extension of the fingers. The test is not associated with Wartenberg’s syndrome. A positive Wartenberg’s sign is indicative of an ulnar nerve injury. If this is seen on evaluation, follow-up  with the referring physician regarding potential ulnar nerve involvement should be considered
Patients who do not improve with conservative treatment are candidates for surgical decompression(11)
treatment summary: There are no randomized controlled studies on the efficacy of treatment for Wartenberg’s syndrome.(1) The removal of external compressing forces (e.g., wristwatch, bracelet) is an extremely important element during initial treatment(1,10)

Treatment for most nerve injuries typically involves rest, splinting, and medication, followed by joint mobilization and strengthening(10) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Increased pain, paresthesia, and hyperesthesiaReduce/resolve symptomsPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Apply peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) or high- intensity transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) to reduce pain(14,15) _ _ Activity modification _ Instruct patient on avoidance of repetitive wrist/forearm rotation, as well as avoiding bracelets and wristwatches.(1) Stress the importance of relative rest of the involved hand.(10) Modify job activities to reduce intensive stress onto the hand/ wrist to help alleviate symptoms(9) _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Fabricate or fit a thumb spica splint/ orthosis to help reduce symptoms(3)N/A Reinforce activity modification concepts along with avoiding external compression onto the forearm/wrist area(1)  Decreased ROM secondary to painNormalize ROM without symptomsManual therapy _ Manual stretching of restricted musculature and mobilization of radiocarpal, radioulnar, and intercarpal joints, if indicated. Mobilization of adhesions, as indicated. Perform neurodynamic interventions by beginning with neural sliding techniques that emphasize the SRN(3)Manual therapy _ Progress neurodynamic interventions with passive neural tensioner techniques that emphasize the SRNInstruct patient on nerve slider or tensioner exercises for self-mobilization. Note that nerve tensioner maneuvers are less complicated and may be easier for patients to reproduce at home(3) Postural deficits Improve posture Patient education _ Educate patient on proper posture concepts _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ Stretch anterior shoulder and chest muscles while strengthening scapular retractors and deep cervical flexorsProgress exercises while maintaining proper postureProvide home exercises along with a posture modification program Decreased strength or potential for muscle atrophy due to disuseImprove or maintain strengthTherapeutic exercises _ Strengthen hand, wrist, forearm, and elbow musculature,(10) ensuring to avoid pain. Also consider strengthening the shoulder for proximal stabilityProgress as appropriate Instruct patient in a home exercise program to complement the physical therapy program, which should be progressed as the patient moves through phases of healing Decreased functional use of involved handNormalize functional ability for ADLs and work-related activitiesFunctional training _ Provide gentle, pain-free functional exercises that simulate ADLs and work-related activitiesProgress exercises by increasing intensity and/or repetition to more closely simulate activity level of the patientProgress home exercise program appropriate for activity of the patient .

maintenance or prevention: Continued avoidance of activities or objects that aggravate the wrist
patient education: For an overview of the anatomy, pathophysiology, etiology, epidemiology and prognosis of radial nerve entrapment (including Wartenberg’s syndrome) as well as presentation, assessment and treatment see “Radial Nerve Entrapment” from Medscape Reference at https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1244110-overview

For an overview of Wartenberg’s syndrome including a diagram of the anatomy and site of compression, see “Wartenberg's Syndrome” from Orthobullets.com at http://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6025/wartenbergs-syndrome Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on May 27, 2016 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
